item.title: The immunity machine

item.title: Secismic hazards and public safety
item.description: IT IS not too late, but time is no longer on Bangladesh’s side. Recent tremors across the country have again exposed a truth long acknowledged by scientists but rarely acted upon by policymakers: Bangladesh remains dangerously unprepared for a major earthquake. Immediate action to integrate geological knowledge into engineering and planning decisions is no......

item.title: Khaleda: liberty leading people
item.description: KHALEDA Zia, the star who could guide the hazy political scene of Bangladesh with steady, firm leadership, fell on the fateful December 30, 2025. The political Ulysses, bound and unbound in the tumultuous power struggle of a postcolonial country, who could navigate Bangladesh over a stormy ocean of uncertainty and danger, left this mortal world. But her......

item.title: Deplorable persistence of old human rights abuses
item.description: AN INCREASE in custodial death, extrajudicial killing and mob violence in 2025 compared with 2024, a year largely marked by political transition and tension, is a sobering reminder that the country has yet to improve its rights situation. The uprising and political changeover of August 2024 raised widespread expectations that the country would finally move away from its grim......

item.title: Economic recovery warrants same weight as political repair
item.description: EXPERTS’ apprehensions that the political process would precedence over economic issues may entirely hold true for the year 2026. This is only natural, with a transition to democracy lying ahead, after the Awami League government, which fell in early August 2024 amidst a mass uprising, had left the political process in disarray. Whilst the Awami League’s authoritarian......
